description.text:
NEW VERSION!
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1810728

Introducing - The "SoC ExoSkeleton"

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=cjATbCNmyYA
FULLY CUSTOMIZABLE! All Drawings Included!

Designed as an "Easy-Print" portable Development Platform for:

Education and Classroom
Programming (C, Python, and many others)
Robotics
Circuit Prototyping
Circuit Design Testing
SoC Testing and Design
Firmware Development
SoC Software Development

Plus...

Portable Gaming (w/Wifi and Bluetooth)(droid, nix and doze!)
Portable NAS
Wifi-Hotspot (with Android SoC)
Octoprint Interface w/touch controls
Portable Penetration Tester
OBD-II Diagnostic Station (Code Scanner)
LED Lighting Controller
LED Signboard Controller
Relay Controller for mid-sized Robotic Machinery
CNC/Laser Cutter Control/Monitoring
Drone Base Station
Tor Node
Portable PRom and EPRom Programmer
And so many more I can't think of...

This system has been designed and sized to fit ANY of the following:

http://www.Adafruit.com (Linux and Android)
Raspberry PI 1
Raspberry PI 2
Raspberry PI 3
Raspberry PI Zero (Both models fit on project boards)
Raspberry PI A and B would likely fit on the Topmost project board. But were not tested.

http://www.Hardkernel.com/ (Linux and Android)
Odroid C0
Odroid C1
Odroid C2
Odroid XU4

http://www.Up-board.org/ (Linux, Windows 7, 8, 8.1, and 10)
Up-board
All Current 2016 Models

Should Fit, but Untested:
Banana Pi
HummingBoard
Beaglebone Black
Lemon Pi
Orange Pi
And Many Others!

The system Build as Shown Uses the Following Hardware:

SoC shown = Odroid Xu4
http://www.hardkernel.com/main/products/prdt_info.php?g_code=G143452239825
$74.00

Specifically designed to use a Rii Bluetooth Ultraslim Wireless Keyboard. K12BT
https://www.amazon.com/Rii-Portable-Wireless-Bluetooth-Stainless/dp/B017QZ483G/ref=sr_1_3?s=electronics&ie=UTF8&qid=1473192283&sr=1-3&keywords=Rii+Bluetooth
$29.00
(Also works with the 2.4 GHz Wireless Version)

Screen Shown = Odroid Vu7
http://www.hardkernel.com/main/products/prdt_info.php?g_code=G144549683088
$55.00
(Can use Vu7+ for higher resolution for only 14$ more)
http://www.hardkernel.com/main/products/prdt_info.php?g_code=G145981837236
$69.00

Battery Used = Anker Astro E3 10000mAh
(1.5-6 Hours life depending on SoC and USBs connected/used. 6Hrs = Screen OFF!)
https://www.amazon.com/Anker-10000mAh-Portable-Gerneration-Technology/dp/B009USAJCC
$26.00

Speakers Used = HP USB Mini Speakers
http://www.ebay.com/itm/HP-Multimedia-Computer-Speakers-630797-001-USB-Powered-Desktop-Laptop-Music/112021578927?_trksid=p2352135.c100669.m3726&_trkparms=aid%3D222007%26algo%3DSIC.MBE%26ao%3D1%26asc%3D37107%26meid%3D80e650864c824d938ae1e205ded37f92%26pid%3D100669%26rk%3D2%26rkt%3D5%26sd%3D222238798129
$11.00

USB Hub Used = Ultra Slim 2.0 4 Port Hub, with DC Port for Powered Hub
http://usbfever.com/index.php?main_page=product_info&cPath=17_92&products_id=439
$12.00

HDMI Cable (LEFT Angled)
http://usbfever.com/index.php?main_page=product_info&cPath=160_162&products_id=2824
$5.00

Sound Card (Only Needed on some SoCs)
https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B00IRVQ0F8/ref=oh_aui_detailpage_o00_s01?ie=UTF8&psc=1
$7.00

5v USB power Cable with Switch (Only needed on some SoCs)
https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B00GGX94JI/ref=oh_aui_detailpage_o00_s00?ie=UTF8&psc=1
$7.00

Project PCBs (Fits TOPmost project plate, must be cut down for lower)
https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B0147YM3DG/ref=oh_aui_detailpage_o00_s00?ie=UTF8&psc=1
5 for $5.00

Some USB micro cables to chop up, and a bit of solder and shrink tubing.
M2 and M3 hardware.

Obviously MOST of the above are optional. All you really need is a Screen, and SoC, a Power source, Bluetooth Keyboard, and some Cables. Oh, and Superglue or Epoxy...

Total with all parts used = $231.00
Taking advantage of shipping deals on Amazon and Ebay, only 12$ in Additional Shipping.

All Features :
The DevTop is completely Flexible in its design, and is pretty much just a final "Rough Draft"
Its meant to be something that has the needed dimensions already there, with tested clearance for the items listed in the build above, and is ready to be redesigned and reshaped or enclosed to your hearts desire!

The design STLs include the Hinge as an individual printable part, that can be bonded or glued to any screen you require, or imported back into Sketchup and added directly into your designs.

The SoC can be mounted front to back or side to side. Depending on Port Placement and User Need.

EASY PRINT... This unit was created with ease of printing in mind. The 2 halves are built to be glued or bonded together after printing, and the Screen prints in one piece. Those 3 Pieces are all that is "Required" to get the Devtop up and running. The Project Plates and LED eyes are Optional.

Hinges are made with a "Tight" Tolerance, to provide a slight tension after inserting the M3 Screws. This allows the screen to hold open or shut, without springs or latches. Just keep the screws Snug.

Hinge is made to bond the 2 Halves together. providing a greater support for larger screens. (10 - 13.1")

Led (Eyes) that Light up with the Monitor Switch or External Switch)

Space Under Keyboard for a Flat 12v AA Battery Pack.

Built in Speakers with USB Power.

2.5" Hdd/SDD/Msata Mounting Tabs (Over Battery)

4 Port Internal USB 2.0 Hub for extra connectivity.

Layback Grooves on the Hinge Backs, allow for an Extra 10 Degrees of Back tilt on the Screen. Make the Monitor Hinge Mounting holes "Taller" for a greater layback.

Open Chassis for Easy Access for Wiring and Cables to Robotics projects, or any other non-chassis mounted project or peripheral.

ALL Sketchup Drawings and STLs are Included. (Showing Progression)
Get the Latest Version of the Monitor, Left and Right Sides to build the most recent revision of the unit. Feel Free to modify and Redesign this unit all you like!

ANY Prusa with a build area of 180x180x140+ can print this model. (Currently)

This was created as a useful purpose to all the SoC projects I had half finished, laying around my house.

Now They all have a chassis I can drop them into interchangeably, as needed, while using my old cases, to protect the SoC when not in use.

Or, With the Up-Board that is soon to ship out, You can have a Ready and waiting Netbook Windows 7, 8, 8.1, and 10 Netbook/Laptop at your disposal as a part of your SoC Arsenal! :-D (Nerd-Gasm!)

For Quick changes and Someone who moves through a lot of electronics projects, I find this unit to be almost a necessity. With enough Flexibility to make it Truly Useful!

A place for Everything, EVERYTHING in its PLACE!

:-P

Enjoy!
Z

Printer Brand:

RepRap

Printer:

FolgerTech Prusa i3 Aluminum 2020

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Doesn't Matter

Resolution:

.12mm - .20mm Layers .4MM nozzle

Infill:

35-60% for Mounting Post Strength

Notes:

Printing under 30% will make weak Mounting posts that break off with ease and cannot be tapped for a screw to be inserted. At that infill, they simply twist right off the model.

Finishing and Bonding... Final Assembly...

Trim the Brim Neatly from all parts. Try to be as Even as possible. The seam will show a lot otherwise.

Glue the 2 halves together by standing them up on a table, one atop the other. This creates just enough pressure to bond them with Superglue. Be sure to glue all contacting surfaces between the two halves. A good bond makes it feel like one piece afterwards.

Gently work the hinges down onto the tabs BEFORE allowing the model to Fully dry. This will ensure the hinges are able to fit, and that the glue (Like Gorilla Glue), cannot push the hinges apart while drying/reacting.

Lay down on Plastic Wrap to Completely Dry. As it peels away easily or can be trimmed.

Add the Speakers as Shown. I Used Gorilla Glue here, and Superglue to bond the halves.
Shorten the speaker and USB cables coming from them to fit into the case, making sure they reach the USB sound card or SoC Sound Jack, and the Battery USB Port.

Screw in the SoC of Choice, Solder up a USB power Cable for the SoC to the Battery and your Monitor, Power it all up, and Connect your Rii Keyboard!

Bam... up and Running!

title: Phlacoplod Worker Drone (18mm scale)
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
An engineered life form used for manual labor throughout the Voolan-controlled sectors of Feudal Space (in our Wayfarer, RPG setting). We're currently Kickstarting a tabletop RPG, Hands of Destiny, so here's a stat block in that system. You can currently find the beta rules (and a module) here on Thingiverse as well.

Phlacoplod
Skills: Aerobics 16, Athletics 2, Brawn 12, Detect 6, Melee 6, Presence 6, Survival 8, Technical 8, Throwing 6
Traits: Expert Climber, Power Lifter, Superior Skill (Climbing), Superior Skill (Lifting), Superior Skill (Technical)
Personality: O/1, C/10, E/1, A/N/A, N/1

We've set up a Patreon page for anyone who's interested in helping to fund us so we can keep making free and open sourced games like Pocket-Tactics, Wayfarer Tactics. and others, not to mention the growing catalog of gaming miniatures that you can use for whatever you want! (Psst... we take requests and commissions...)

Enjoy!

title: Arrosage automatique pour plante à base d'Arduino nano

description.text:
Arduino (pro nano) hygrometer with OLED display, clock (Ds3231 RTC module) and pump control.

A simple project to drive a little 5v pump when your plant require watering, or simply display moisture level.

Based on dfrobot capacitive moisture sensor : https://www.dfrobot.com/index.php?route=product/product&product_id=1385 and a low cost pump

You will find source code here : https://github.com/pnomblot/hygrometrePlante

Enjoy !
DS3231 I2C RTC CLOCK + OLED I2C + DFROBOT capacitive soil moisture + pump

It needs two small ball bearing (Diameter=8mm, Width=4mm). I buy them at Aliexpress.

This is a replacement for the lousy little squirrel cage fan on the Taz 5 Hexagon Hotend.

There is a Taz 6 mount you can make but I didn't want to have to print the entire assembly just to get a better fan on the vanes. This is a simple solution that I hope helps others than me. It required no modifications to the Taz other than wiring in the new fan.

It takes a 25mm M2 bolt w/washer to mount to the original cage fan hole, or you can do what I did and order 20mm bolts by mistake and have to drill out 5mm of the hole to make it fit. I don't recommend it. ;)

I had originally linked to a fan on Amazon, but that fan ended up sucking so I removed it from the description. Any 40mm 5V fan should work, keep the current rating to 20ma or below and you should be fine.

This is a TINY rail gun... half.

To make a rail gun, purchase 15 magnets, 1/8 x 1/8 x 1/2 inch in dimensions:
https://www.kjmagnetics.com/proddetail.asp?prod=B228

Print 2 of the M15365_RailGun_1.

stick the magnets in the spaces provided with all the North poles facing either inside or outside (does not matter, but they must be the same)

I used clear tape to hold the magnets in while putting the rest in... they tend to wanna slip out until you are done.

you should have one magnet left...
mount your 2 rail gun halves (tape or glue) to something sturdy with a 1/8th inch slot between them.then simply push your leftover magnet through the slot left between them.

does the north side first shoot further or the south side first?

NOTE: This is a tiny, crappy rail gun, it wont shoot more than a couple inches, even if you have everything aligned perfectly. If you are off a bit, you can likely not fire at all...

CHALLENGE: Remix this to make it longer and see if you get better results.

Small screwdriver bits holders compatible with Small storage system.

I wanted to print the Archimedean Solids before doing the Catalans, thing:17137, but it was not possible at that time. Two lists are required to make an openSCAD polygon command: 1) a list of vertices and 2) a list of triangles which connect the vertices to make the surface. For many polyhedra the netlib library has a list of vertices and a list of faces; my program converts the list of faces to a list of triangles. However the netlib library does not have vertex or face information for the Archimedean Solids. Archimedean vertices are available from Wikipedia and
I decided to revise my code so that only vertices are required. I changed my fortran program to work in two steps. In step one it produces a set of vertices for an Archimedean solid scaled to
mimic a cage molecule. The scaled vertices are input into a molecular modeling program. I used VMD from the University of Illinois. VMD shows the polyhedron as a wire frame model with labeled vertices. I then made, by inspection, a list of faces to be input into the second step of the program. Output is a polyhedron command. It looks possible to program the whole process but as only 13 solids were involved I chose to use my existing code and identify the faces by hand. The time spent looking at wire frame models made me realize how nice they look and how little material would be necessary to print them. Then I came across the truncated icosahedron - ah the Buckyball - see thing 12675. The 60 atoms of the Buckyball fit onto the 60 vertices of the truncated icosahedron. All of the edges of an Archimedean polyhedron have the same length so one could use the Buckyball program to make ball and stick and wire frame models of all of the Archimedean solids. The complete set of hollow Archimedean stl files is in hollow_archimedean_stl.zip and the scad files used to produce them are in hollow_archimedean_scad.zip. Note that errors are always possible. All 13 files produced attractive models. The maximum dimension is about 50 mm so as to print quickly but scaling up should be possible. Six of my favorites are included as stl files (see images) :
hollow_cuboctohedron.stl
hollow_trunc_octahedron.stl
hollow_rhombi_cuboctohedron.stl
hollow_icosidodecahedron.stl
hollow_trunc_dodecahedron.stl
hollow_trunc_icosahedron.stl

The files were printed on a Thing-O-Matic using a smooth heated surface.  Kapton tape, cleaned with acetone, covered the surface. No external support was required as all of the Archimedeans have large faces available. I used rafts.

title: Better Organizer Box Dividers
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
I printed one of the other organizer box (like the Plano's or the Flambeau's tackle box organizers) dividers here on Thingiverse, and it worked fine. But the ones that came with my Flambeau had nice little finger grips on them. So I designed a new one from scratch with FreeCad, and put in nice little finger grips on them.

Basically you can make this fit any size organizer that uses this style of divider. Simply adjust the x,y, & z dimensions in your slicer program to match the one for your orgnanizer.

The large STL file is from FreeCad. I redesigned them in the new TinkerCad Beta editor and those are the r2 (revision 2) files.

Ok, so I noticed that one of the corners of the TinkerCad version was a bit off, so I fixed it. This is the new TinkerCad r3 file.

Cube than can be used to assemble perpendicular pieces.  
The holes go all the way through, and are offset so that a screw can be put into each hole (it can be used in a box corner).  
The holes were sized so that a #8 screw will "bite" securely without cracking the cube.  However I found that some of the cubes I printed were cracking, so now I drill out the holes with a 5/32 bit.  The screws fit much more loosely, but still bite the threads sufficiently.  
They are also countersunk so that a "deck mate" type screw head will sit (nearly) flush.  For that purpose, I drill out the hole larger so that the screw passes through freely, and anchors into the surface behind.
Use ABS, PLA will be too brittle.

title: J Tech Photonics Laser heat sink cable holder to take away tension

description.text:
This is a cable holder for a laser i bought from J Tech Photonics (http://jtechphotonics.com).

The holder keeps the tension away from the soldering points within the enclosure while the laser is in movement. Without this holder there is a chance that the cable will detach
from the laser-led at some point, which actually happend to me.

The cable grabber has a very tight fit, you maybe need to use some pliers to push the cable in.

If you have a longer bolt then me, use some washers to fill the gap. If your bolt is shorter you can use some sanding tool to adapt the holder.

If you really need to be sure that the cable stays in place there is a little hole ment for a zip-tie

One side has an longer edge that is ment to fit into the enclosure rail to keep the holder from spinning.

Would love to see some builds !

Notes:

Made in ABS because I like ABS as an engineering plastic, but would work just as well in PLA.
I run my platform at 110C and the extruder at 230C.

Earlier I had designed a faithfull replacement washing machine knob.
I had designed a stub to slip over the shaft and then glue on the knob. It was neccessary to make two pieces in order to print.
Using the same stub but modifying the flat section to fit any standard potentiometer or wafer switch, I designed a new knob which slipped down over the wafter switch nut to hide it as it finished flush with the surface, and has one side with a longer protrusion to that it pointed to the appropriate device in operation.
(In my case this was a speaker selector panel between two different amplifiers).
Its big to be able to grip both protrusions. It falls nicely between fingers and thumb. The stub and knob are a tight fit together so at the moment I have not glued it in case I want to change it at another time.

This is a decorative grill that can be placed over vent holes approximately 6.5cm in diameter. Specifically, the grill has a 6.5cm inside diameter and a 9.5mm outside diameter. OpenSCAD source files are included in case you want to tweak or scale the design. Under the eaves of one part of my house, there are vent holes that lead into the attic. All of these vent holes have wire mesh covers, except for the ones that don't. In the vent holes missing their mesh, wisps of pink insulation, like cotton candy, are pulled through. I am not certain whether this is from birds or rats, but I thought that replacing the grills was a good idea, especially given the recent influx of attic rats. More information is available on the blog post at: http://netninja.com/2013/11/02/attic-rats-lead-to-custom-printed-vent-covers

• Print with a good amount of infill.
  • Attach using screws with tapered heads. I used #8 x 3/4" stainless sheet metal screws.

title: Epic Scale Imperial Guard Infantry Proxy

description.text:
a generic human infantry cookie shape. nothing fancy, just an outline to put models on the table.

bit of paint should add to the effect and en masse they should look the part... from a distance.... and squint a bit.

update 2017-06-04] have added the bases here for convenience and also the thudd gun model. i have a couple of stands with 1 thudd and 2 infantry - works fine.

[update 2017-06-01] i have used this as knight world 'infantry levy' units and they work fine.

there are 5 different outlines/poses including a sword/pistol wielding commander type chap.

i'm preferring the slotted base/models method over the one-piece complete model and base (like the earlier eldar models) because it allows for individual printing of the pieces so if you get a bad blob you can just chuck it. additionally, printing 'side on' pieces makes a much much much cleaner model. the eldar ones can be pretty gribbly and mangled once you take out the support sections.

description.text:
This is a door latch extender that will allow you to open a door but not let it open all the way.

The reason for this could be for a really dumb dog that likes to eat poop out of a cat box. So, perhaps, you would like to keep this sed dog out of the laundry room where the kitty litter box resides. This allows the cat to get in and out but not the dog.

...or you may have other reasons for it.

There are two versions: Split and No Split

Since my printer was so small I had to make the model in two pieces. If you are like most people you can just download the "no split" STL and that should be all you need.

I added two holes at the end so you could pick between two opening widths.

Printer:

Micro M3D

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.25

Infill:

100%

Notes:

I used gray ABS on my Micro M3D printer... but I also have a heated bed on the M3D

It is 150mm long

if you use the split model...

you can use Acetone to weld the ABS together.

Used OnShape

It is public in OnShape, just search for "Door Latch Extender"

title: Case for zrib board, zonestar P802Q

description.text:
Bonjour ,

pour mon tout premier partage ici , je vous propose un boitier pour board "ZRIB" .
Ne trouvant pas de boitier pour mon imprimante (P802Q de Zonestar) que je vient d'acheter ,j'ai décider d'en faire un !!!

le voila !!!

pour le montage il vous faudra 4 vis M3 x 12 avec les écrous et 4 vis M3 x 14 avec les écrous aussi . Et pensez a supprimer les cale plastique d'origine 

                                                    MISE A JOUR

Apres le retour d'un maker , qui à eu un souci avec le couvercle qui touchais le moteur de l'axe X en homing , j'ai corriger le fichier , normalement cela ne devrais plus ce produire .

n'hésitez pas à me dire si il y à un problème , ce qui est bon chez moi ne l'est peut être pas chez vous .

le 10/09/2016 Ajout du fichier pour l'écope d'air a l'arrière du boitier ,pour éviter le flux d'air sur le plateau chauffant .

###############################################

Hello ,

for my first share here, I offer a case for board "ZRIB".
Finding no box for my printer (P802Q of Zonestar) I just bought, I decide to make a !!!

here it is !!!

for installation you will need 4 M3 x 12 screws with nuts and 4 screws M3 x 14 with nuts too. And think has to remove the original plastic wedge

                                                           UPDATE

After the return of a maker who had a problem with the lid touching the engine of the X axis homing, I fix the file, normally it should not produce it.

please tell me if there is a problem, what is good in me do may not be home.

09/10/2016 Added the file to air scoop at the back of the case, to prevent the flow of air over the heating plate.

comments.text:
Hello ,
On my printer I shortened all the wires to gain from the place and a large part of the wires its passed behind the card, and everything fits well in the box.

sinon , le fan c'est du 120mm ou du 80mm ?

comments.text:
Salut , c'est prévu pour un fan de 80 ou 90 mm . avec l'écope ça vas, l'air est expulsé vers le haut ça gène pas, et la majeur partie de l'air sort par le trou des fils en fait .
J'ai fais comme ça pour être au plus compact et avoir une ventilation surdimensionnée . ;)

description.text: remake of the below thing. still a work in progress but it works on my printer now. needed to move the mount for the hot end because it hung down to low and i lost 2-3 inches of print area. you can use all the same hardware that came with your Anet/Prusa printer. use the hollow threaded rod that mounted the mk8 hot end to the lower part of the filament tension bracket and use that to secure the stepper motor to the e3d hot end. spin the e3d hot end until the motor secures to the mount. this is hard to explain and I'm sorry. I'm sure anyone who 3d prints is technically inclined enough to figure out what I'm talking about.

comments.text: This is what I have so far, I am going to try and mount it in an hour or so. I added support for the print fan to the left, I made the piece that secures the hot end more compact, I thinned out the left side of the mount and I moved up the belt mount screw holes by 3mm.

comments.text: I printed it up, started to install it but it is causing binding. I am using IGUS bearings and they fit the rods exactly. Once the bearing blocks were tightened for the x axis, it is very tight to slide the extruder carriage side to side and also the bolts that would be used to secure the x axis belt to aren't aligned (sticking out far enough) and the belt rubs along the side of the idler. Re-thinking this.
comments.author: IsmaelPR1

comments.text: I was confused because it worked for me lol.  Did you get it all set up then?

comments.text: The setup I have isn't going to work, I am going to remix it to place the print cooling fan on the left with the heat break cooling fan to the right with an extended duct. For the print fan duct that I have I need to change some of the dimensions, I am also going to raise the belt screw locations by 3mm.

author: ccooksey

description.text:
Remixed from the m3 Wing Nut by Dr_3d - thank you for the jump start!

I originally remixed these to keep the nuts on my CTC from digging down into the particle board when tightening the exterior screws. Coincidentally they also work very well for holding the nuts in place when disassembling/reassembling the bot.

In most cases, one of the thin edges will need to be removed for the perfect fit. (pictured) One of the edges should be particularly easy to remove - again by coincidence, one of the corners didn't join all the way on my model.

This .stl file contains 40 nut covers, which should be enough to cover all of the visible nuts - plus a couple extra (for the bottom of the bot).

Printed in PLA
.20mm layers
100% infill
no raft/supports

Update - 19th Sept - made this into a customizer.

An adapter to connect a small DC motor (found in many toys or cheaply available) with a 2mm diameter shaft to a lego technic 'x'.

I've found that a 2.2mm hole provides a good tight fit, this may vary with different printers and materials, so the scad file is there for you to experiment with. You should also be easily able to vary the length of the shaft if you need to.

Printing in PLA at 100% fill has given me consistent results.

Balco

No

0.1

100%

print_settings.Notes:: Recommend printing at high level of infill.. this part needs to be strong.

description.text: Seems most people have trouble mounting cameras to the RMRC Gobi 210's very miniscule build platform. I couldn't find a single build that could accommodate a CCD camera between 25mm standoffs, so I designed this mount as a two-piece part - one is the bracket that screws into the second set of holes, the other is a replacement backing plate for the camera itself.. You may have to clearance the carbon fiber cutout above the front standoffs. Swapping to smaller diameter or round standoffs would be helpful. This mount allows for approximately 13-39 degrees of camera angle, which should be enough for most people. Enjoy!

DaVinci 1.0

Yes

No

60%

Notes:

Recommend printing at high level of infill.. this part needs to be strong.

I don't print ABS, so unsure if it will work for that. Should do, though....

author: archie73

title: X4R-SB or D4I-II FRSKY Receiver Mount... PDB/FC 30mm bolt pattern

description.text: I needed a tight receiver mount for a space-limited quadcopter build.. this was what I came up with. It is 8mm tall and and holds a de-pinned FRSKY receiver nicely. You can easily slot a corner for the smart-bus wire, and I've included a lid for people that have PDB's with errant pins underneath. 8mm hexagon standoffs press fit into the reliefs, and you can sandwich your receiver safely underneath your other electronics. Works great. I potted mine, but it'll be secure with or without glue/epoxy. The holes are slotted in the thin model to accommodate the different antenna PCB locations between the two receivers, but I will add the X4i receiver-specific model later. The D4R model is ready to go. Enjoy!

author: masterolly

title: square and rectangular tube cap and joiner generator
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Customizer OpenSCAD program to generate custom caps and joiners for square and rectangular tubing/pipe. This is a rewrite of custom plug/cap for square or rectangular tube with corrections and new features, including the ability to create joiners for connecting two pieces of (same size) tubing.

This version works the same as the previous one with the addition of three new inputs in Customizer: "Build Item", "Ribs", and "Orientation".

"Build item" selects whether a cap or a joiner is being built. Joiners are similar to caps with retaining tabs on both sides (plus some extra extension and reinforcing of the tabs). For joiners the cap taper does not apply and the internal hollow goes through the "cap" portion. The "Recess pct" controls how large to make this internal opening.

The retaining tab portion of the cap/joiner now has an option for ribs instead of or in addition to the grooves. Ribs run perpendicular to grooves with wider spacing and are intended to fit easier into tubes with rough interiors. The "Ribs" input allows this feature to be turned on.

Typically the most straightforward way to print a cap/plug is with the retaining tabs pointing upward which generally does not require any supports. However if the cap was printed on its side it might be stronger because the layers would run perpendicular to the tube edge and possible shear forces. Since a joiner could benefit from stronger tabs the "Orientation" option allows the selection of a sideways (horizontal) build position. Unlike caps, joiners probably need supports when printed in any orientation. When built horizontally the joiner is rotated to rest on a corner to minimize the amount of supports required. This works well with square caps and joiners, but may might not be stable when the tube/item is rectangular.

Further enhancements include thicker tabs for strength, changes in outward angle of tabs for larger caps for better fit, reduction of false surfaces in preview, and a clearer error message when tubing is to small for the tab sizing formula.

Homo ergaster (meaning "working man") or African Homo erectus is an extinct chronospecies of the genus Homo that lived in eastern and southern Africa during the early Pleistocene, that is, between 1.9 million and 1.4 million years ago. It is one of the earliest hominins, which are those hominids that comprise the original members and species of the human clade after splitting from the line of the chimpanzees. Homo ergaster is variously thought to be ancestral to, or as sharing a common ancestor with, or as being the same species as, Homo erectus. - Wikipedia, https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Homo_ergaster

Great model for learning about evolution.

Includes front bumper, TS5828 Video transmitter mount (with space for heat sink and NACA duct to cool), a slide-in D4R-II / X4R receiver mount, landing gear, motor guards, and a useful antenna mounting solution that uses zip-ties to secure everything. I've also included a zip-tie mount for the battery connector, but it only works if you modify a bottom plate as a top plate (thicker and stronger)... All of it is crash-tested and fits excellent. I will update the front bumper to add a small taper towards the top; at high camera angles it is visible and slightly annoying.. Sure beats smashing a $40 camera though.. Enjoy!

REVISION- (9-12-16) Receiver mount has changed.. Instead of two round sweeps, the antennas now exit through a 45 degree "block"... this allows you to use either vertical antenna tubes, using the clip; or to simply insert two 3mm antenna tubes to have them exit the rear in a 45 degree array. May hold up better for crashes, we will see. Also changed the "hex" texture on the outer panel and removed a section for prop clearance.

author: KellyRoos

description.text:
Heavily based on Gossamer's parametric Tardis.
I altered the doors to be bevelled for easier mold release and tweaked a few values here and there for better parametricity.
Then I subtracted from a block, and added holes for skewers to help alignment, tabs also to help alignment and to assist in mold release by percussion, and slots to hold string or zip-ties or rubber bands to hold the mold together during pouring.
UNTESTED, post pics if this works for you!
The two numbers in the STL filenames are 1) the 'H' parameter (height from base to top of door) and 2) the width of the entire STL.

1) Print mold halves. Either a combined pair, or each half separately, or choose your own adventure using the scad.
2) Line mold halves with some sort of release agent. butter perhaps?
3) Join mold halves. use skewers for alignment, add rubber bands or string to hold together
4) Heat chocolate to 28-32Â° celsius. Do not exceed 33.8Â° celsius or you'll have to re-temper your chocolate! See http://chocolatealchemy.com/illustrated-tempering/
5) Pour
6) Allow to cool.
7) Separate halves, use gentle percussion if necessary. The tabs were added for exactly this purpose as well as aiding alignment
8) Consume and enjoy!

ESC Armor.
1) Double sided tape the esc to the arm
2) slide cover over ESC with the open bottom design.
3) fix with two small zip ties.
*indestructible from prop strikes.
;)

I probably won't be redesigning these any time soon (unless someone feels like making a sizable donation to compensate me for the time and effort it would take). However, if you ask me I can send you the files and you are free to modify them yourself (everything was designed using 123Design)

description.text:
If you're a fan of the X-Wing Miniatures Game by Fantasy Flight Games, you've probably heard of the fan-made Heroes of Aturi Cluster Co-op Campaign - if not, today is you're lucky day. Go check out the link. You can come back and thank me later. ;)

Anyway, I've spent a few months working on making 3D-files of all the terrain pieces for the campaign kit, as well as a few useful accessories. They're finally done and ready for you to print out and play with.

Enjoy! :D

TERRAIN LIST
File Name / Quantity Needed / Special Instructions

  • Fuel Tank / 9 needed / -
  • Sensor Array / 3 needed / -
  • Cargo Container / 12 needed / -
  • Shield Generator / 4 needed / -
  • Command Center / 2 needed / -
  • Turret Bottom / 6 needed / -
  • Turret Top / 6 needed / attaches to spindle on Turret Bottom. Should spin freely.
  • Station1 / 2 needed / -
  • Station2 / 6 needed / -
  • Station-docking bay 1 / 2 needed / -
  • Station-docking bay 2 / 2 needed / Glue or tape part 1 & 2 together to form a complete piece.
  • Station 6-hub / 1 needed / This piece is too large for most print beds. I have included a file for printing it in smaller sections (station 6-hub split v3- print out 3 copies and tape/glue together to form a complete piece)
  • Station 3-hub / 3 needed / -
  • Minefield / 18 needed / I have included 2 versions of the minefield. The "filled" minefields have a solid background for stability. The "open" minefields do not have a background filled in, so they require less filament to print and they match the design of the ion clouds (I prefer the "open" minefields personally, but they are a little flimsy).
  • ion clouds / 1 of each file needed / Most of the ion clouds are too large to print out in 1 piece, and have been divided into smaller sections (ie: 1a and 1b). Tape and glue these together to form 1 piece.

Accessories: These are not part of the v0.7 campaign kit, but I have found them to be useful (especially the base overlays). Print out however many you so desire.

File Name / Description

  • Small Base Overlay / Place over AI-controlled ships to give you guidelines for determining which maneuver table to use. Very handy.
  • Large Base Overlay / Same as the small base overlays, but for large ships.
  • Deployment Guide / Use to quickly and easily set up imperial squadrons in formation. Pretty straight forward to use: place the end of the guide with the arrow against the edge of the board, and then place the squadrons in the respective slots (the ship with the highest squad number goes in the spot with 4 nubs, and so on down to the spot with 1 nub).
  • 1XP token / I thought it would be handy to have tokens for tracking XP earned.
  • 5XP token / Same as the 1XP token, but worth 5 XP each
  • Assist Token / Used for tracking assists (as per the assist rules that Josh outlines in the comment section of the v0.7 faq)

Printer:

Da Vinci Jr 1.0

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Notes:

All of the pieces are thin and flat, you shouldn't need anything special to print them out.

Note that I designed these to work with my printer. If some parts are a little loose or tight with your printer... well, sorry about that. I probably won't be redesigning these any time soon (unless someone feels like making a sizable donation to compensate me for the time and effort it would take). However, if you ask me I can send you the files and you are free to modify them yourself (everything was designed using 123Design)

Large Terrain pieces

My print bed is 6"x6", but some of the terrain pieces are larger than that. For those pieces I have cut them into smaller sections that my printer can handle. They will require some gluing and/or taping to assemble them. They should be fairly self-explanatory, but if you have any questions just ask me in the comments.

Turrets

The Turrets come in two sections, a top and a bottom. They should snap together fairly easily and rotate smoothly.

A few months ago when I started printing out the Heroes of the Aturi Cluster campaign kit for the X-Wing Miniatures Game I thought it would be awesome to 3D-print some turret pieces that could rotate around. So I made one. And then I figured I should maybe make some of the other terrain pieces too, and one thing led to another, and well, after many hours of work, here we are. ;)

Special Thanks

I want to thank the following groups and individuals:

  • Fantasy Flight Games, for creating such an awesome game.

  • Josh Derksen & his friends/playtesters, for creating such an awesome co-op expansion. It's obvious that they put many many hours of work into testing and tweaking and perfecting the campaign, and the end result (or well, beta version 0.7 at this point in time) is incredible!

  • George Lucas, Lucasfilm, and Disney for bringing the Star Wars universe to me. It's shaped my life in more ways than I care to admit.

  • Most of all, my wife, for putting up with many endless hours of me staring at a computer screen and ignoring her while I worked on these designs.

author: nerdymark

description.text:
This is the second revision of an enclosure for the rear of a RMRC GOBI based quad, to securely mount a TS5828 Video Transmitter in the confined build space between the top plate and base plate with 25mm standoffs. This slides over the 5mm diameter hex standoffs for a very secure mount. The VTX locks into the square recess nicely as soon as the antenna is torqued. Provides a very clean method of attaching VTX and three antennas, while keeping everything clean and undamaged. You will have to slightly notch the fiberglass board of the VTX to clear the standoffs, but performance will be unaffected.

LED panel is a RGB Matek 3-led unit. 3mm antenna tubes mount in front of it to be secured to the arms.

Discovered in 1969 near the city of Wuwei, in the province of Gansu, it is now in the Gansu Provincial Museum.

author: Slinger2712

description.text:
I designed this to wind up excess motor/endstop/extruder wires and zip tie them to make things neater. This can be mounted to 2040 or 4040 v slot extrusion (i use openbuilds) using m5x10mm bolts and post assembly t-nuts.

How it works:

1) Insert the zip tie through the middle hole and leave it unzipped

2) Play with the number of wraps around the prongs until you have the right amount of slack to reach your electronics, etc... You can do normal winds, or weave them. If the approach angle of the wiring coming into the part is pretty awkward, you can do one wrap around the nearest prong, then start wrapping around both.

3) Close and tighten the zip tie around the wraps of wires.

4) Drink beer

Change Log

9/7/2016 - There was an issue with the zip tie piece not printing with the first stl. I have uploaded a fixed version. I tested this morning and it works great. I added some photos and am marking this complete for now, but let me know if you want any kind of remix, such as longer prongs, 4 screw holes etc...
A heart shaped box with lid. This was one of my first projects in Sketchup and when better to publish it than on Valentine's day!
You may want to scale the walls shorter on the actual box.

comments.text: I LOVE this print!  I am an occupational therapy assistant in an elementary school.  I use this all the time.  My kids have come up with great ways to play.  Here is my favorite.  I use therapy putty, but it could also be done in play dough.  I hide the number and press the bottom into the putty.  The child then counts the dots.  Once they have the right answer, they press the number flat into the putty.  Then they trace the imprint with their finger to work on number formation.  Last is writing the number on paper.  The child then has to use their fingers to "erase" the imprints in the putty, which gives sensory input and works on strengthening their fine motor muscles.

title: rad = rA(x), the trigonometric multipurpose wall rack!
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Introducing rad = rA(x), a wall-mountable, inch-thick, mathematically precise sine curve that also serves as a multipurpose organization rack! I originally designed this (in OpenSCAD) with the intention of using it to keep some of my 3D printing supplies (e.g., filament spools, rolls of blue tape, etc.) tidy & readily accessible on the wall above my printer, but this can also easily be used as a coat rack, a hat rack, or simply a large, plastic, prominently displayed testament to just how giant a nerd you actually are. (Though let's get serious, this is a 3D printing community: who among us isn't a nerd?)

As you can see, each spindle on the rack doubles as a marker along the curve for the intersection between everyone's favorite radian increments, namely pi and all her lovely sisters (3 pi over 2 is particularly adorable, is she not?) and their corresponding sine values. So mount this puppy on the wall, step back and bask in all its trigonometric glory!

Also included is a specially designed mounting alignment device; instructions for its use are below.

rad = rA(x) dimensions (fully assembled)
weight (in PLA filament with 15% infill) = 493 g = 0.493 kg
width = 21.75" = 55.25 cm
height = 12" = 30.5 cm

Printer:

Flux Delta

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

15%

Notes:

Mounting alignment device printed as above but with infill of 10%.

How to Assemble & Mount

The rack comes in 7 segments, which must be assembled in order from left to right after printing, using the dovetail joints to connect adjacent segments. These have been carefully designed to fit very snugly, but depending on the tolerance of your printer, you may need to sand down some of the male dovetails with a rotary sander to get them to fit.

Four of the segments have screw holes to allow for wall mounting. I strongly advise using these holes to make guide marks on your wall for your drill holes. The holes in the rack are sized to accommodate standard wall mounting screws. Use drywall anchors if mounting to drywall.

I recommend the following steps:

1) Assemble the first 3 segments together & make the first two guide marks on the wall with this, using the mounting alignment device to ensure that it's level, as shown below.

** Note that segment 1 and segment 7 have little protrusions at the curvy end, which are designed to fit into the slots of the mounting alignment device (just flip it upside down to switch from one piece to the other).

2) Drill the first 2 holes & mount the first 3 segments to the wall.

3) Assemble the remaining 4 segments together & connect these to the first 3 segments.

4) Use the screw holes to make guide marks, ensuring that segment 7 is level, as you did before with segment 1. Remove the 4 segments to drill the remaining 2 mounting holes.

5) Reconnect the last 4 segments to the first 3 segments & mount them to the wall. You're done!

After the rack has been mounted to the wall, use the four screw caps to fill in the four holes. The caps have also been carefully designed to fit very snugly, and should need neither glue to keep them in place nor sanding for them to fit. Note that there are two stl files for the screw caps: one comprises all four of the caps and the other enables you to print a single cap at a time in case you need to replace any.

I designed the rad = r(A)x from start to finish in OpenSCAD, principally as a means of teaching myself how to use the software.

(You can ignore the rest of this section unless you're interested in the particulars of the OpenSCAD code I wrote. Apologies for the formatting, or lack thereof; that's due to the site's text editor, not me.)

The easy part was the base equation, which was included in the following block of code:

module sineCurve( ) {
for (x = [origin:curveLength]) {
translate([x * xMultiplier), sin(x) * amplitude])
circle(radius);
}
}

where 'origin', 'curveLength', 'xMultiplier', 'amplitude' and 'radius' are all variable parameters declared elsewhere in the code. The linear_extrude function was then applied to an iteration of the sineCurve module, varying the values of 'origin' and 'curveLength' to produce each segment of the sine curve.

The spindles were placed as follows:

angles = [ [1, 90 * xMultiplier,1],
[0, 180 * xMultiplier, 1],
[-1, 270 * xMultiplier, 3],
[0, 360 * xMultiplier, 2] ];

module spindle( ) {
translate([0, 0, thickness/2])
rotate([-20, 0, 0])
cylinder(r = radius/3, h = 6 * thickness);
}

(where 'thickness' is the parameter used to declare the height of the linear extrusion of sineCurve).

spindle( ); // this is equivalent to a module call of spindle( ) with placement at the origin.

// this places all subsequent spindles at specified locations along the curve:
for (i = angles) {
translate( [ i[1], i[0] * amplitude, 0 ] )
spindle( );
}

Bonus points if you can tell me what the third value in each matrix of the 'angles' matrix of matrices was used for (in another block of code not shown here). ;)

The most difficult part, believe it or not, was getting those dag-blasted dovetails in place. In total the project took me 3 intense days of trial and error but I learned a lot! Coding is fun, especially when it yields tangible objects that are pretty and useful. :)

In the end I was pretty happy with the result. I hope you are too.

description.text:
My Mom is a math teacher and she needed some fraction pieces for her students. After I made the set, I figured other teachers might like to use it, too.
-They're circles it's clear how many pieces are left for the whole, no fill-in trays needed.
-The numerators are inset and the denominators are extruded to try and convey that the numerators are just pieces that fill up the whole denominator.
-I originally printed them at 1cm thick, but I found it to be overkill, 5mm is plenty strong enough.
If you know a teacher, please let them know about this set, since these kinds of plastic kits can be expensive!

title: Extruder Knob - 5mm shaft
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
I needed a better knob than the stock for the EZ-Struder on my Rostock Max V2, by SeeMeCNC. Original slipped on the shaft, and hurt my hands to turn since I don't have calluses, ha. So, I whipped up this new one. Fits tightly on the shaft.

This should fit any 5mm diameter shaft, with a 0.5mm cutout for the setscrew.

Edit 20161206: updated scad source with better parameterization and depth of shaft cutout, and added two improved models. Both new files (20161206) for 6mm shafts -- one for extruder, other for a 10-position rotary switch.

Printer Brand:

SeeMeCNC

Printer:

Rostock MAX BYOE

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

go coarse for speed

Infill:

25%

Notes:

Printed in PLA. The shaft opening is tight, so you might have to very slightly enlarge to get to fit on yours.

Material doesn't matter. Go cheap.

Created in OpenSCAD.

Knob handle part is an extruded 6-sided circle, which has been Minkowski-summed with a small sphere to give the rounded edges.

Shaft is the difference between a cylinder and two other things: 1) the shaped cylinder for fitting over the shaft, and 2) another rotated cylinder for the setscrew.

I uploaded source, so you can modify it to your liking. Also, so you see how Minkowski works, because it's cool. In fact Minkowski sums come into play when computing the number of roots for a polyhedral start system when solving a multivariate system of polynomials. Fun fact for the day.

Share & Enjoy!

title: Minimalist Desk Organizer
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Keep your desk nice and tidy with this minimalist organizer. At 100% scale, the side partition is wide enough to hold two tape dispensers, but obviously you can scale to whatever size you would like to fit your printer.
I've also made it available as a single piece or as a top and bottom, in case you would like to break up the print time, or re-orient the way the partitions are positioned.

Printer Brand:

Robo 3D

Printer:

R1 ABS + PLA Model

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.3mm

Infill:

25%

Notes:

Due to the size and surface area of this project, I would highly recommend using PLA.
If you print the pieces separately, you may need a raft for the top of the organizer to prevent curling. I only used glue and a heated bed and managed to get away with it. There was curling, but less than a millimeter so I didn't mind.

Combining/strengthening the pieces

It's pretty straight forward, just glue the two pieces together with the partitions oriented however you would like.
I would also recommend a small amount of glue to the middle of the key cylinder. The orientation of the print isn't great for strength on that part, however keys are so light it should never really be an issue. The glue is simply an optional precaution.

description.text:
These rails are great to keep all the wires from your USB hub tucked neatly away UNDER your laptop. Each piece is long enough to hold your laptop without issue, yet short enough to stay away from the hot, back charging port, so heat won't be an issue. I printed these in PLA and I've had zero issue with the temperature warping over time. It's also super easy to remove your laptop, just lift it right up, no hooks to worry about.
These work well for 13" laptops, however I would consider a 20% scale length wise if your computer is a 15" model.

This is a very simple RAMPS/Arduino mount we use mainly for machine debugging. As most of our machines no longer use the RAMPS 1.4 configuration I tend to use this when I'm doing debugging work on other machines.

As the title suggests, this is a very simple mount, it's thin allowing for some flex. The fastening holes allow for M3 bolts to be fastened directly into the part or you may use a nut and the flexibility allows for some play when attaching the RAMPS or when fastening the mount to another object.

As is the mount can be fastened to a typical 12v LCD power supply flexing to lift the board off the metal PSU case.

This was made to serve as a temporary or permanent mount for developing. These are nice for preventing any incidental shorts or unwanted contact while working with the RAMPS board.

Tonight's 3Doodle. :-) It will print, as is, with support material for the lever arm. Use an Xacto Pen to clean up the post gapping. There always seems to be some stray filaments when printing gear in sprocket items. All that the thing needs to be finished is a rubberband stretched between the 2 opposing posts with the band looping through the lever arm hole. Make sure to loop the rubberband because it helps hold the hand on the post and centers the upright position. Give it a push. :-) Have a nice day.
Bill.

title: C10 Duo - Dual radial cooling fan mount and duct for Tevo Tarantula

description.text:
I've printed out a few fan ducts for the Tevo Tarantula but i was looking for a fan/duct setup that gave good cooling but also doesn't obscure the hotend tip.

Making it possible to easily see the distance of the hotend from the print bed, see how that first layer is going down and giving space to quickly pull out those pesky bits of loose filament, if any are floating about. But also be light compact and extend as little as possible from the front of the x carriage keeping things as balanced as possible.

So i thought i'd have a go at designing my own version.

I've taken inspiration from the Atom 2.0 Delta 3D printer which Thomas Sanladerer did a live build of on his Youtube channel. This Delta printer uses two metal body compact (40x40x10mm) radial fans for its cooling.

Atom 2.0 Delta Printer
http://www.atom3dp.com/en/atom2/

Rather than use the metal body radial fans i was able to get a plastic version from Aliexpress.
http://s.click.aliexpress.com/e/7qnMBUj
12VDC and 24VDC versions available if you need.

The top mounts use the four hotend mounting holes and screws on the top of the x carriage.
The fans press fit into the top mounting bracket arms (no screws).
And the lower fan ducts fit over the radial fan body (no screws).

You will need to print:
Two fan brackets (left and right)
Two fan ducts (left and right)
And you'll need to buy 2 x radial fans (one for each side).

These fan brackets and ducts are designed to work with the stock Tevo Tarantula hotend only.

I've run a few prints through the printer with this new cooling setup in PLA and i've noticed a visible improvement in the print accuracy particularly around over hangs and small details.

Update

Having seen fan ducts being tested, on the Tevo Tarantula facebook group, using a glass of water i thought i'd see how my design performed. The glass of water helps to visualise the air pressure created by the fan duct, much better than using your finger or a piece of paper.

It turns out that my original design doesn't perform that well using this visual aid. The focus of the ducts is very broad, not focused around the nozzle and is located behind/in front of the nozzle.

So with this new info to hand and with some new and improved Fusion 360 skills i set out to create a new version.
This time with better air focus around the nozzle.

One thing i found is that with a more focused air flow around the nozzle this can affected the hotend temperature stability. So to counter this i changed to an e3D V6 clone heatblock and matching silicone heat block sock. This has been great for keeping a stable hotend temperature and i would highly recommend fitting one. This also reduces the heat transferred into the nearby fan duct.

Version 2:

This new version has smaller duct outlets, more sweeping contours and tweaked geometry. These changes result in better air pressure focus around the nozzle.

Printer:

Tevo Tarantula Prusa i3

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

20%

Notes:

Infill only needed for the top brackets.
This can be printed in PLA. But if you don't have a silicone sock or cotton wrap around your heat block it may start to deform where its close. So printing the ducts with ABS may be a better option in this case.

comments.text:
looks really good and compact, going to try this and get the radial fan. love the simple atom design too.
i was having not enough airflow with other fan duct. can feel air back flow when hand over the fan input.
comments.author: JosephChoo

comments.text: I was also not getting great air flow with other circular style fan ducts. But i was using the stock 40 mm fan that comes with the kit. So an upgrade to a better 40 mm fan might have helped. But i think i've ended up with a better solution overall as a result. Interested to hear how you go with yours.
comments.author: JosephChoo

comments.text: i used the stock fan and also tried a delta 40mm fan on those circular style duct too. without mounting the fan, the air flow pressure were great but once it is mounted; i can feel back flow by placing my hand over the fan inlet; seem bottleneck at the duct outlet. air flow at the hotend were very faint.
comments.author: code10

comments.text: I've just uploaded a photo showing the difference the radial fans made when printing the 3dbenchy model. Sorry about the image quality but the over hang was a big improvement. A bit hard to make out with the black model.
comments.author: JosephChoo

comments.text: What is "Occupy Thingiverse"?
comments.author: Andrew1618033

comments.text: It's a rebuttal of Thingiverse's ToS change whereby they "take ownership" of any material loaded onto Thingiverse. They do this to protect themselves from Copyright laws. I haven't heard of a single case where Thingiverse took someones thing and made money from it.

title: LWC Airsoft shower Pocket Claymore " P.C"

description.text:
Ever wanted a functional mini Airsoft Claymore? With the pocket Claymore or short " P.C" you got one. Fully functional spring loaded belt propelled airsoft BB mine.
Universal mounting options with wodden sticks in the forest floor, sand or gravel.
With a belt on trees and other Things.
The tripwire can be used in different directions with universal tripwire leads.
Tripwire splint activated.
Easy to find again with bright signal colors once it was activated.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=DOBvy5BH49o

Printer:

Delta

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.3

Infill:

the lid at least 35% the base part should be fine with 30%

Notes:

The hinge is hugely reinforce but still the biggest weak point of the whole system, so make sure you have enough infill so it wont break on you.
The more infill on the lid the heavier and also " slower" will the BB´s be propelled by the sping loaded Belt.
The lighter the lid is the faster and snappier it swings open with the danger it will break easier.

Print the lid and the base with support from the print bed in horizontal position.

You need some additional parts for this build like:

2x mouse traps ( standard spring loaded mousetraps)
4x m3 rope clamps
8x m3 nuts ( additional to the ones already on the rope clamps)
1x m4 25mm Screw + nut for the hinge
2 x m5 metal Washer ( you can also use a small coin)
some kind of splint ( whatever you want to use like a toothpick, a piece of metal wire .....)
Ducktape, pliers, isolation tape, a thin but solid wire like fishing line,

title: LED Strip Mount for FFCP Cable Tie Screws or Standalone

description.text:
I wanted to add some white LED light strips to my FlashForge Creator Pro and wanted to attach them to the cable tie screws on the vertical supports and at an angle. I found several LED strip mounts online, but nothing quite like I was wanting, so I designed one in OpenSCAD and parameterized it for easy customization.

I am presently using two of these strips on my 2016 FFCP printer, one on each of the front vertical supports or corners. They can easily be mounted on the other two corners as well for even more light, but I figured this would be enough extra light and a good starting point.

My final design that I used on my printer is rendered in the accompanying .STL files. These were designed to use the standard 30cm 15-LED White Light Strips with 3 LEDs cut off to fit the corners. The parameters for the strip width and spacing in the OpenSCAD file are for that configuration.

Note that these 15-LED strips are wired in groups of 3 LEDs and can be reduced in length by cutting them off in groups of 3. The original 300mm was too long to fit on the corners, but 12-LEDs or 244mm is about perfect.

I also wanted them to be mounted at a 45-degree angle, but made that a configurable parameter too. They attach to the three cable tie screws on the vertical supports (or corners) of the printer with 3mm nuts. If you are attaching it to a vertical support that already has cable ties, use some 3mmx12mm or similar stand-offs to clear the cable ties.

I also designed it to be rendered either as a single piece or as a left/right half that can be joined together with glue and/or acetone (if using ABS). The FFCP can print these as a single piece, but just barely and only if you rotate it 60-degrees.

To change the part rendered, just edit the RenderType variable. 0=Full Part, 1=Left Half, and 2=Right Half. The RenderSplit variable determines where the split is to be made (presently at 60%). If changing that, be sure not to split on one of the mounting tongues or it won't work correctly.

The cut shape when rendering as left/right halves is controlled by the RenderCutMag array and RenderCutCount variable, which must be the number of points in RenderCutMag, minus 1, as it represents the number of actual line segments for the cut.

Supports aren't needed unless you alter the angle to something that requires it. Just flip it over to print flat. And no raft is needed. I did print it at 100% infill to make the long thin mount a bit stronger. Though the infill setting makes little difference in amount of filament used.

This LED Strip Mount isn't limited to the FFCP nor to 3D printers at all. With a little customization, it can be used for mounting LED Strips on nearly anything.

Printer:

FlashForge Creator Pro

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

100%

Print the full piece or print individual pieces and join them together. Trim and attach LED strip. Bolt into corner vertical support using 3mm nuts to attach it to the cable tie screws. Wire it up and enjoy the extra light.

comments.text: How did you wire these up. Where on the board did you get your power?
comments.author: knuckleup10

comments.text: I got the power for them directly from the +24V power supply.  Though I overly complicated mine by using a buck-regulator converter to make 12V from the 24V supply and adding connectors for multiple LED strips.  The LED strips I used are rated for 12V (generally for automotive use) and so I needed to reduce the 24V to 12V. So I 3D printed a little case for a buck-regulator (which you can get on Amazon or eBay, etc), added a switch for controlling LED power, and wired several connectors for multiple LED strips to its output (in parallel), allowing me to run one, two, three, or more LED strips.
comments.author: knuckleup10
